title: 109_hr4203
content: The Windfall Profits Rebate Act of 2005 imposes a windfall profits tax on crude oil, with specific provisions for removal price, adjusted base price, and qualified investment. The Windfall Profits Rebate Act of 2005 imposes an excise tax on integrated oil companies for windfall profits from taxable crude oil removed from properties, with provisions for fractional barrels and tax payment by producers. The Windfall Profits Rebate Act of 2005 defines windfall profit as the excess of the removal price of taxable crude oil over the adjusted base price. The removal price is determined by the amount for which the oil is sold, with specific rules for sales between related persons and oil removed from property before sale. The Windfall Profits Rebate Act of 2005 defines windfall profit as the excess of the removal price of taxable crude oil over the adjusted base price, which is $40 for each barrel of crude oil plus an additional amount. If crude oil is refined on the property before removal, the removal price is considered the constructive sales price for income determination. The Windfall Profits Rebate Act of 2005 defines windfall profit as the excess of the removal price of taxable crude oil over the adjusted base price, which is $40 for each barrel of crude oil plus an additional amount determined by an inflation adjustment formula. The first revision of the price deflator is used for determining qualified investments, which include section 263(c) costs, qualified refinery property, qualified facilities under section 45(d), and alcohol production facilities for fuel under section 40. The term 'section 263(c) costs' refers to intangible drilling and development costs that can be deducted as expenses, excluding costs for drilling nonproductive wells. "SEC. 5898. SPECIAL RULES AND DEFINITIONS." The Secretary will establish rules for withholding and depositing the tax on taxable crude oil. Taxpayers must maintain records, submit returns, and provide information as required. The Secretary will outline the filing process for the tax return. Definitions include 'producer' as the holder of economic interest in crude oil, and 'crude oil' encompasses specific types. The term 'crude oil' includes condensates and natural gasoline. Newly discovered oil is excluded unless produced from a well drilled on proven oil or gas property. A 'barrel' is defined as 42 US gallons. The Secretary may adjust removal prices to reflect fair market value, and regulations will be prescribed. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this chapter. The section does not apply to taxable crude oil after 3 years from enactment. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. Chapter 56 discusses windfall profit on crude oil. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a deduction for the windfall profit tax on crude oil. The effective date for this amendment applies to crude oil removed after the enactment date of the Act, for taxable years ending after that date. Transitional rules are in place until December 31, 2005, for the administration of chapter 56 of the Internal Revenue Code. The administrative provisions in chapter 56 of the Internal Revenue Code (or subtitle F related to chapter 56) are subject to transitional rules until December 31, 2005. SEC. 6430. ENERGY CONSUMER REBATE is a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing rules for energy consumer rebates. The new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, SEC. 6430, outlines rules for energy consumer rebates. Each individual is treated as having made a payment against the tax imposed by chapter 1 for each taxable year, based on the lesser of their previous year's tax liability or the applicable amount. The liability for tax is calculated as the excess of the taxpayer's regular tax liability, tax imposed by section 55(a), and social security taxes for the taxable year. The taxpayer's social security taxes for the taxable year minus the allowable credits under part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The applicable amount is determined by the Secretary based on the number of taxpayers and Treasury revenues from the previous year's tax. Payment is deemed made on February 1 of the following calendar year. The Windfall Profits Rebate Act of 2005 states that payments to taxpayers shall be made by the Secretary within 30 days of February 1 of the calendar year. Certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens are not eligible for this rebate. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to title 31, United States Code. The Windfall Profits Rebate Act of 2005 requires payments to taxpayers within 30 days of February 1. Certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens are not eligible for the rebate. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. The Windfall Profits Rebate Act of 2005 mandates energy consumer rebates, effective upon enactment of the Act.
